bioghist.p: Carrie Lane Chapman Catt (1859-1947) was an internationally recognized suffragist, feminist, and political activist. She served two terms as President of the National American Woman Suffrage Association, and is credited with revitalizing the NAWSA during the struggle for passage of the nineteenth federal amendment granting suffrage to women. Catt founded the International Woman Suffrage Alliance in 1902 (later the International Alliance of Women) and served as its president for many years. She formed the League of Women Voters in 1920 and was its honorary president until her death in 1947. In 1925, Catt founded the National Committee on the Cause and Cure of War. During the 1930s and 1940s, Catt was active in working against the Nazis, particularly their persecution of Jews. Although she was a champion of world peace, Catt was a vocal supporter of the Allied Forces during World War II.

scopecontent.p: This collection consists of papers of Carrie Chapman Catt. Materials include: correspondence; speeches and lectures; scrapbooks; suffrage cartoons (c. 1915-1920); newspaper clippings (1909-1943); articles by notable suffragists, such as the British playwright Laurence Housman; and suffrage ephemera. Correspondents include Susan B. Anthony's niece, Lucy Anthony, and Woodrow Wilson. Speeches include an address entitled "A League of Nations," an address at the Democratic National Convention in Philadelphia in 1912, and talks given at the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences (1905) and Bryn Mawr College (1921).

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
